sub_topic: Identifying the Eulerian and Hamiltonian paths in a graph.
message_1:
Consider the following graph:

```
    A --- B
    |     |
    C --- D
```

Does this graph have an Eulerian path? If so, what is it? If not, explain why. Does this graph have a Hamiltonian path? If so, what is it? If not, explain why.
message_2:
An Eulerian path is a path in a graph that visits every edge exactly once. A graph has an Eulerian path if and only if it has exactly 0 or 2 vertices with an odd degree (number of edges connected to the vertex). In this graph, all vertices have a degree of 2, which is even. Therefore, this graph has an Eulerian path. One possible Eulerian path is A-C-D-B-A.

A Hamiltonian path is a path in a graph that visits every vertex exactly once. This graph has a Hamiltonian path as well. One possible Hamiltonian path is A-B-D-C.
